__data__.text: Nagaenthran a/l K. Dharmalingam, a Malaysian of Indian descent from Ipoh, was born on September 13, 1988, and is the second of four siblings, including an older sister named Sharmila and a younger brother named Navinkumar.

Nagaenthran's father passed away while he was on death row in Singapore. During his childhood, his mother, Panchalai, worked and left him and his siblings in the care of their grandmother and relatives. As Nagaenthran grew older, Panchalai became his primary caregiver but had limited communication with him due to her job.

After finishing secondary school at 17, Nagaenthran started working in a factory. Disregarding his family's concerns, particularly his mother's, he moved to Singapore for work, becoming a security guard there. He would regularly travel back to Ipoh to visit his family.

Upon completing secondary school, Nagaenthran relocated to Singapore for work, taking a job as a security guard and regularly traveling back to Ipoh to see his family. His last visit to his hometown occurred during Deepavali in 2008, as stated by his sister. In 2009, at the age of 20, Nagaenthran was apprehended by Central Narcotics Bureau officers for drug trafficking while traveling from Malaysia to Singapore through the Woodlands Checkpoint.

After moving to Singapore for work, Nagaenthran was caught carrying drugs from Malaysia during Deepavali in 2009. Officers found 42.72g of heroin hidden on his thigh, which he admitted was given to him by a Chinese friend named "King". His travel companion, Kumarsen, was also arrested but released later.

Upon relocating to Singapore for work, Nagaenthran was apprehended for transporting drugs from Malaysia during Deepavali in 2009. He initially admitted to carrying the drugs to settle personal debts and medical expenses for his father's heart surgery. However, he later recanted his confession, denying knowledge of the drug bundle and alleging that King, his Chinese friend, had coerced him through threats to his girlfriend's life.

After moving to Singapore for work, Nagaenthran was arrested for transporting drugs and was subsequently charged with capital drug trafficking, as the amount of heroin exceeded the minimum limit for the death penalty. Despite his claims that he was coerced, he was found guilty and sentenced to death by hanging on November 22, 2010.

The High Court and Court of Appeal in Singapore rejected Nagaenthran's argument that he was coerced into committing the drug trafficking crime. The judges held him fully responsible for his actions and dismissed his appeal. Nagaenthran sought re-sentencing, along with legal changes and a re-sentencing application.

Note: This summary is a concise paraphrase of the original text, retaining all propositions and able to replace the original text in the given context.

Following the rejection of Nagaenthran's appeal and his responsibility for the drug trafficking crime, he sought re-sentencing and proposed legal modifications. In July 2012, a year later, Singapore implemented changes to its death penalty regulations, imposing a halt on all executions, including Nagaenthran's. This summary captures the original text's key points, condenses the information, and maintains the original text's meaning.

In 2012, Singapore paused executions, including Nagaenthran's, after updating its death penalty rules in January 2013. These amendments allowed judges to give life imprisonment with at least 15 caning strokes instead of death to couriers who assist the narcotics police in disrupting drug trafficking activities, provided the public prosecutor grants them a certificate of substantial help.

In 2013, Singapore introduced new death penalty rules, offering alternatives to the death sentence: life imprisonment with caning could be given instead if the offender assists the narcotics police in disrupting drug trafficking activities or has diminished responsibility due to mental illness. Nagaenthran, whose execution was initially paused, sought re-sentencing due to his claimed clinical intellectual disability and mental illness. However, a psychiatric evaluation determined that he did not have these conditions.

In 2015, Nagaenthran, whose execution was previously halted, applied for re-sentencing due to claimed intellectual disability and mental illness, which were both ruled out by a psychiatric evaluation. He also didn't receive a certificate of substantial assistance from the Central Narcotics Bureau as he didn't significantly aid in disrupting drug trafficking activities. Nevertheless, Nagaenthran requested mercy from the High Court, citing an intellectual disability, low IQ, impaired executive functioning, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, conditions that could have made him ineligible for the death penalty.

In 2017, the High Court rejected Nagaenthran's application for re-sentencing, concluding that he did not have an intellectual disability. Four mental health experts, including one supported by the defense, concurred on this point. The court also noted Nagaenthran's history of inconsistently reporting his educational background, which appeared to decrease with each interview.

In 2017 and 2018, the High Court determined that Nagaenthran did not have an intellectual disability, as agreed upon by multiple mental health experts. They also noted his history of inconsistently reporting his educational background. Additionally, the court observed that Nagaenthran demonstrated manipulative and evasive behavior during his offense, attempting to prevent officers from searching him by claiming he worked in security to exploit the perception of security officers' trustworthiness. The court rejected further appeals in 2018, leading to a Court of Appeal review.

In 2019, Nagaenthran, through his lawyer Eugene Thuraisingam, filed two appeals with the Court of Appeal, seeking to have his sentence reduced under recently implemented death penalty regulations. However, the five-judge Court of Appeal dismissed both appeals on May 27th. The court found numerous inconsistencies in Nagaenthran's description of his crime, which undermined his defense's credibility.

In 2019, Nagaenthran, represented by his lawyer, appealed to the Court of Appeal to reduce his sentence based on new death penalty regulations. However, the five-judge panel, comprising Sundaresh Menon, Belinda Ang, Andrew Phang, Judith Prakash, and Chao Hick Tin, rejected his appeals on May 27th. They concluded that, despite his low IQ, Nagaenthran's mental capacity was not significantly affected during the commission of the crime. He demonstrated planning and organizational skills, and was capable of independent living. Furthermore, Nagaenthran was aware that importing heroin was illegal and took steps to conceal the drugs to evade detection.

In 2019, Nagaenthran's appeal to reduce his sentence was denied by a five-judge panel, including Sundaresh Menon, Belinda Ang, Andrew Phang, Judith Prakash, and Chao Hick Tin. Despite his low IQ, the court found that his mental capacity was not significantly impacted during the crime. Nagaenthran demonstrated planning skills, lived independently, and understood the illegal nature of his actions. He attempted to avoid detection and conceal drugs, showing deliberate and calculated behavior, which was viewed as evidence of a "criminal mind." His attempts to pay off debts and weigh consequences indicated an awareness of right and wrong. This decision led to a clemency petition and increased public attention.

In 2020, Nagaenthran sought clemency from Singapore's President Halimah Yacob, hoping to reduce his death sentence to life imprisonment. However, his plea was denied on June 1, finalizing his capital punishment. This development attracted significant public attention, as the last granted clemency in Singapore was in 1998 for a 19-year-old convicted of murder.

In 2012, Mathavakannan was released early from his life sentence due to good behavior after serving 16 years. As Nagaenthran's clemency appeal unfolded in 2020, his case gained international attention, with many calling for Singapore to abandon the death penalty for him. His mother, Panchalai Supermaniam, and family were also part of the appeals for mercy. This reference was made in a 2019 news report.

In a 2019 news report, a Malaysian human rights lawyer, N. Surendran, criticized Singapore for unfairly sentencing a mentally disabled man, Nagaenthran, to death. Surendran and Nagaenthran's new lawyer, M. Ravi, claimed that Nagaenthran's defense's psychiatric evidence was not adequately considered during the trial, compared to the prosecution's psychiatrists' reports. This criticism arose in the context of previous accusations that Singapore was biased against Malaysian drug traffickers, as an increasing number of Malaysians were being executed for drug trafficking. Singapore's law minister, K. Shanmugam, had already addressed these concerns.

In response to criticisms of bias, Singapore's law minister, K. Shanmugam, asserted that both locals and foreigners are treated equally under the law for drug trafficking. He mentioned that Singaporean citizens generally support capital punishment and suggested that it would be beneficial if Malaysian authorities apprehended drug traffickers, as they would then be subject to Malaysian laws instead of facing Singapore's death penalty. Shanmugam also highlighted the importance of maintaining the fairness of Singapore's legal system by avoiding special treatment for Malaysian prisoners on death row. The text further discusses legal actions such as the issuance of a death warrant and a stay of execution, with the execution date being confirmed.

Following criticisms of bias, Singapore's law minister, K. Shanmugam, emphasized equal treatment under the law for both local and foreign drug traffickers, discouraging special treatment for Malaysian prisoners on death row. While Nagaenthran's execution was initially postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the informal moratorium on capital punishment eventually ended, leading to the confirmation of Nagaenthran's execution date.

After Nagaenthran's clemency appeal was rejected, his execution was initially delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, resulting in a year's reprieve. Ultimately, the Singapore Prison Service sent a letter to Nagaenthran's family, announcing that he would be executed on 10 November 2021.

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) has offered to assist Nagaenthran's family with travel arrangements, including quarantine procedures and COVID-19 testing, and will allow extended daily visits with multiple visitors, while implementing measures to minimize COVID-19 risks in the prison, given the local transmission rates. The last execution in Singapore prior to this was in November 2019.

In the context provided, the text indicates that the most recent execution in Singapore occurred on November 22, 2019, when Abd Helmi Ab Halim, a 36-year-old man, was put to death for trafficking more than 16g of heroin in 2015. This execution took place despite appeals from Malaysia to spare his life. It's worth noting that there has been opposition to capital punishment. Additionally, the SPS has proposed measures to assist Nagaenthran's family with travel arrangements and visits while minimizing COVID-19 risks in the prison.

Upon learning about the execution plans, Malaysian lawyers and various international and local organizations advocating against the death penalty, such as the World Coalition Against the Death Penalty, Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International, United Nations Commission on Human Rights, and FIDH, urged the Singapore government to grant clemency to Nagaenthran. They argued that Nagaenthran had an intellectual disability, which impaired his understanding of his actions and the consequences, and therefore, he should not be subjected to capital punishment. Furthermore, they maintained his innocence and called for a reevaluation of his case.

After the announcement of the execution plans, advocates against the death penalty, including Malaysian lawyers and organizations like the World Coalition Against the Death Penalty, Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International, and others, petitioned the Singaporean government for clemency on behalf of Nagaenthran. They claimed that Nagaenthran had an intellectual disability, which affected his comprehension of his actions and their consequences, and thus, he should be exempt from capital punishment. They also questioned his guilt and requested a reexamination of his case.

Additionally, an online petition was initiated to appeal to President Halimah Yacob to save Nagaenthran's life, which gathered over 102,000 signatures. There are also plans to present the case to the International Court of Justice (ICJ), alleging that Singapore's non-compliance with international norms against the death penalty is a violation of international human rights and law, particularly in regards to the execution of mentally unfit offenders.

In the US, the Social Justice Divisions of the American Psychiatric Association have criticized Nagaenthran's case, deeming it a clear violation of human rights, echoing the concerns raised by Malaysian lawyers, advocacy groups, and the online petition. These parties argue that Nagaenthran's intellectual disability impairs his understanding of his actions and their consequences, which should exempt him from capital punishment. They also question his guilt and seek a reevaluation of his case. Furthermore, they intend to bring the case before the International Court of Justice, asserting that Singapore's non-compliance with international norms against the death penalty, particularly for mentally unfit offenders, infringes upon international human rights and law.

Human rights groups have urged pressure on Singapore to abolish the death penalty, emphasizing the need for mercy in Nagaenthran's case. Public figures such as Subhas Nair and Richard Branson, as well as family members of other death row convicts, have joined in requesting clemency for Nagaenthran, echoing the concerns of the Social Justice Divisions of the American Psychiatric Association, Malaysian lawyers, and advocacy groups. They argue for reevaluating Nagaenthran's case due to his intellectual disability and question his guilt, aiming to take the case to the International Court of Justice to challenge Singapore's non-compliance with international norms against capital punishment, particularly for mentally unfit offenders.

Demonstrations took place in Malaysia's Parliament in Kuala Lumpur, calling for increased governmental action to prevent Nagaenthran's execution. His sister, Sarmila Dharmalingam, shared that she and her siblings had kept the news of their brother's impending execution from their mother, eventually informing her five days after receiving the notice. The mother reacted negatively to the distressing information.

Following the demonstrations in Malaysia's Parliament regarding Nagaenthran's execution, diplomats from the Malaysian embassy visited his family in Singapore to offer consular support. This assistance was facilitated by abolitionist advocate Kirsten Han and her activist group, who also successfully raised over $14,000 in just two days to cover travel, accommodation, and funeral expenses for Nagaenthran's family.

After the Malaysian embassy's visit, facilitated by Kirsten Han and her group, Nagaenthran's mother was able to travel to Singapore and reunite with her son after a gap of three years. During this visit, one of Nagaenthran's brothers, Navinkumar Dharmalingam, noticed that his brother appeared to be significantly disoriented, differing from his previous visits.

Following the embassy visit, Nagaenthran's mother reunited with him after three years, during which his brother, Navinkumar, observed significant changes in his behavior. Nagaenthran appeared disoriented, smiling inappropriately, and struggling to make eye contact or recall people he knew, except for his mother. A nearby death row inmate mentioned that Nagaenthran had been quiet and isolated for over a year, not speaking to anyone.

After observing Nagaenthran's behavior during the embassy visit, his lawyer, M Ravi, grew concerned that Nagaenthran might not fully understand his impending execution. Ravi noted that Nagaenthran's mental health seemed to have worsened during his 11-year imprisonment, causing him to behave similarly to a young child. This behavior, combined with Nagaenthran's isolation and disorientation, suggested to Ravi that the extended period on death row had a detrimental impact on Nagaenthran's mental well-being.

Amnesty International's researcher, Rachel Chhoa-Howard, criticized the court's disregard of Nagaenthran's claims of diminished responsibility, finding it reprehensible to execute someone for drug trafficking when they may not fully comprehend the situation. She also expressed concern over the execution's timing, scheduled just six days after Deepavali, a significant Hindu festival for Nagaenthran and his family, preventing them from properly celebrating it. This reflects the negative impact of the prolonged imprisonment on Nagaenthran's mental well-being.

An individual was apprehended for displaying a poster against Nagaenthran's death penalty, deemed as an unlawful act of incitement. The Ministry of Home Affairs responded to growing calls for clemency by asserting that Nagaenthran received complete legal process and continuous representation. This statement follows the criticism of Amnesty International regarding the court's dismissal of Nagaenthran's diminished responsibility claims and the insensitive scheduling of the execution during Deepavali, impacting his mental health.

The authorities declared that Nagaenthran was given complete legal process and had legal representation throughout. They reaffirmed the court's ruling that Nagaenthran acted without coercion, was not significantly mentally impaired to prevent execution, and fully comprehended the consequences of his actions. Therefore, they saw no reason to reconsider his case as all appeal options were already exhausted.

The authorities reiterated that Nagaenthran's case had undergone full legal proceedings, and there was no basis for reconsideration. The amount of heroin he trafficked could supply around 510 addicts for a week, justifying the severe punishment. Singapore maintains that the death penalty is crucial in keeping its low crime rates and preventing drug-related destruction. Nagaenthran's execution date remained set for November 10, 2021.

The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has clarified that severe penalties, including the death penalty, for drug trafficking are explicitly communicated at Singapore's borders. Additionally, other death row inmates, not named, have had their execution dates scheduled after exhausting all appeal options. In response to Nagaenthran's impending execution, a Malaysian lawyer, Mahajoth Singh, staged a solo protest in front of the Singapore High Commission in Kuala Lumpur on October 31, 2021.

Surendran, a Malaysian lawyer, pleads for Nagaenthran's life, emphasizing that executing him due to his mental disability is unjustified. Lawyers for Liberty in Malaysia criticize Singapore's government for disregarding Nagaenthran's mental state and for their reaction to mercy appeals. The Malaysian Prime Minister, Ismail Sabri Yaakob, has urged Singapore's Prime Minister, Lee Hsien Loong, to reconsider Nagaenthran's case and withdraw his death sentence.

Ismail Sabri Yaakob, the Malaysian Prime Minister, and Saifuddin Abdullah, the foreign minister, have expressed their hope that Singapore will grant Nagaenthran a reevaluation of his case and exercise discretion in deciding his clemency. They emphasized Malaysia's respect for Singapore's laws while advocating for a fair and considerate approach towards Nagaenthran's sentencing, taking into account his mental disability.

The European Union, which opposes capital punishment, has joined Malaysia in urging Singapore to spare Nagaenthran from execution. A last-ditch appeal was made on November 8, and M Ravi presented the case at the High Court. Nagaenthran's COVID-19 infection was not mentioned in the text.

The High Court rejected the appeal to halt Nagaenthran's execution, as Judge See Kee Oon stated that there are no legal grounds to delay it, given the absence of evidence supporting the claim of Nagaenthran's deteriorating mental state or his mental age being under 18. The court has already exhausted all appeal options since 2019.

The High Court judge, See Kee Oon, dismissed M Ravi's appeal to stop Nagaenthran's execution, citing a lack of evidence supporting Nagaenthran's alleged deteriorating mental state or him being under 18. Ravi, lacking medical expertise, had met Nagaenthran only once, six days before the appeal hearing, for 26 minutes. The judge also rejected Ravi's international law arguments, asserting that domestic law prevails. Nagaenthran's appeals were exhausted, including one heard on 9 November 2021 at the Court of Appeal.

On November 9, 2021, an appeal was taken to the Court of Appeal, which was met with criticism from lawyer N. Surendran, who believed the quick timeline infringed on Nagaenthran's right to a fair trial. In the High Court hearing, prison officers' testimonies contradicted the claims of Nagaenthran's allegedly deteriorating mental state.

Two prison officers, who have had regular interactions with Nagaenthran for several years, did not observe any abnormal behavior from him. In fact, Nagaenthran was able to communicate effectively with the officers in multiple languages and even requested religious counseling despite knowing about his impending execution.

In the days leading up to his execution, Nagaenthran displayed typical behavior and successfully sought religious guidance, contacted his family, and chose specific prison officers to assist him, as detailed in the text.

Prior to his execution, Nagaenthran had acted as expected and received religious guidance, connected with his family, and selected certain prison officers for assistance. In the context of this, the Attorney-General's Chambers attempted to share Nagaenthran's recent psychiatric records with his lawyer, who objected to the disclosure. Also, on the day of the appeal at the Court of Appeal, Malaysia's Communications and Multimedia minister, Annuar Musa, had conveyed his hope to Singapore to reevaluate Nagaenthran's case and grant him clemency.

While the Attorney-General's Chambers tried to share Nagaenthran's psychiatric records with his lawyer, who objected to the disclosure, human rights experts from the United Nations urged Singapore to grant clemency to Nagaenthran. However, his execution was postponed to an unspecified date because he tested positive for COVID-19 just before his appeal hearing on November 9, 2021. The postponement was communicated to both Ravi and the prosecutor Wong Woon Kwong in a crowded courtroom filled with local and international media and activists.

Nagaenthran's appeal was postponed to give him time to recover from COVID-19, as he tested positive for the virus. The court hearing with judges Andrew Phang, Judith Prakash, and Kannan Ramesh was initially scheduled for November 10, but was delayed due to his infection. It was later disclosed that Nagaenthran didn't show any symptoms before the ART test, which initially came back negative. However, the PCR test results confirmed his infection, leading to the postponement of the appeal hearing.

Nagaenthran declined to get the COVID-19 vaccine, despite a high vaccination rate among prisoners and staff at Changi Prison's Institution A1. After testing positive, he was isolated, and the death row cells where he resided were put on lockdown due to additional cases among prisoners and officers. This information was disclosed during the discussion of Nagaenthran's postponed court hearing, which was delayed after an initial negative COVID-19 test was later contradicted by PCR results.

The text mentions that along with the measures for regular COVID-19 testing of prisoners and staff at Changi Prison's Institution A1, there have been reports of 169 infected prisoners, including some on death row, as of November 12, 2021. This revelation comes as Nagaenthran's court hearing was postponed following conflicting COVID-19 test results. The case has highlighted the debate surrounding the death penalty in Malaysia.

The text discusses the contentious issue of the death penalty in Malaysia, which has been highlighted by Nagaenthran's court hearing postponement due to conflicting COVID-19 test results. Although human rights groups advocate for the abolition of capital punishment, many Malaysians think that it should still be implemented for severe crimes like murder and specific corruption offenses, excluding drug trafficking. Despite a decrease in new death sentences given by courts, public support for the death penalty in Malaysia remains strong.

Legal professionals, including lawyers and police officers, have suggested that judges should have the discretion to impose life imprisonment in certain capital cases, taking into account mitigating circumstances. However, they believe that the death penalty remains relevant for severe crimes such as drug trafficking, murder, and other offenses, considering the high rate of drug-related crimes in Malaysia. This perspective was shared during a budget debate by Datuk Seri Nazri Abdul Aziz.

During a budget debate, Datuk Seri Nazri Abdul Aziz proposed that Malaysia reevaluate its death penalty laws for drug trafficking, as the current approach of executing drug offenders while seeking mercy for Malaysian citizens abroad is inconsistent. This suggestion comes in response to the case of Nagaenthran and the increasing UN pressure to pardon him, recognizing the growing global movement towards leniency in drug-related crimes.

During the UN's calls for clemency towards Nagaenthran, Singapore's UN representative, Ambassador Umej Bhatia, has stated that Singaporean courts have carefully evaluated Nagaenthran's mental state and found he did not have a mild intellectual disability, as his personal psychiatrist also confirmed. This statement emphasizes that Nagaenthran's execution eligibility has already received thorough examination.

In response to the UN's plea for clemency, Singapore's UN representative, Ambassador Umej Bhatia, highlighted that Nagaenthran's mental state was rigorously assessed by Singaporean courts, and his personal psychiatrist concurred that he did not have a mild intellectual disability. Regarding the UN's claim of violating international law, Singapore argued that there is no global consensus on the death penalty or the definition of "serious crimes," granting countries the sovereign right to determine their capital offenses and use of the death penalty.

Singapore rejected the UN's accusations that Nagaenthran's case was influenced by the prosecution and unfair to his family, asserting the independence of the prosecution and the option for appeal. They also maintained that COVID-19 travel restrictions were not biased against Nagaenthran's family.

Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that COVID-19 travel restrictions for individuals entering Singapore from Malaysia, including Nagaenthran's family, were non-discriminatory and uniformly applied to all travelers. These restrictions were implemented to manage the ongoing pandemic situation in the country. Officials attempted to communicate with Nagaenthran's family to clarify the travel regulations and assist them during their stay in Singapore. The statement also mentioned that Singapore's leaders, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan, had been involved in the matter.

Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan, informed Malaysian authorities that Nagaenthran is receiving due process according to the law and has been deemed not intellectually disabled by courts and psychiatric evaluations, so there is no need for external intervention in his case.

Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs asserts that Nagaenthran is receiving proper legal treatment and is not intellectually disabled, hence external intervention is unnecessary. However, Malaysian human rights lawyer N. Surendran and Lawyers for Liberty argue that the Singapore government is falsely claiming Nagaenthran's full due process, as the courts allegedly failed to consider his intellectual and mental impairments during the trial and did not make accommodations for them.

Human Rights Watch's senior disability rights expert, Emina Ćerimović, strongly criticized Nagaenthran's case, describing the Singaporean government's actions as inhumane and shocking. She argued that pursuing the execution of a person with an intellectual disability for importing a small amount of drugs is disproportionate, cruel, and merits global condemnation. This aligns with the stance of Malaysian human rights lawyer N. Surendran and Lawyers for Liberty, who claim that the Singapore government did not provide Nagaenthran with his full due process rights, as his intellectual and mental impairments were not considered during the trial, and accommodations were not made for them.

The Malaysian Bar, Advocates Association of Sarawak, and Sabah Law Society have appealed to the Singaporean government for clemency in Nagaenthran's case, requesting that his death sentence be reduced to life imprisonment. They emphasize their respect for Singapore's laws while expressing concern about Nagaenthran's mental state due to the potential psychological impact of his 11-year death row period. They urge Singapore to evaluate his mental competence before carrying out the execution. This aligns with the criticisms of Human Rights Watch and Lawyers for Liberty, who argue that the Singaporean government failed to consider Nagaenthran's intellectual and mental impairments during the trial and did not provide necessary accommodations.

Nagaenthran's family and lawyer, M Ravi, plan to take legal action against Singapore's attorney general, Lucien Wong, for negligence and disregard of human life. Ravi received a letter from Wong, warning him of consequences for "contempt of court" regarding his previous allegations against the legal system in Nagaenthran's case. Ravi is expected to withdraw his claims and apologize by November 22.

Ravi, the lawyer for Nagaenthran, has declared that he will not withdraw his statements or apologize to the attorney general, Lucien Wong, despite receiving a warning for potential contempt of court. Meanwhile, the Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia has written to Singapore's President, advocating for clemency for Nagaenthran. The Court of Appeal in Singapore is set to deliver its final decision on Nagaenthran's appeal on November 30, following a hearing on November 26.

The court date for Nagaenthran's appeal has been postponed to January 2022, as announced by activist Angelia Pranthaman, whose brother was also on death row. M Ravi, Nagaenthran's lawyer, requested the adjournment and confirmed that no new date has been set. Angelia has pleaded for clemency for both Nagaenthran and her brother, whose sentences are for drug offenses.

Nagaenthran's lawyer, M Ravi, was temporarily unable to represent him due to his suspension from legal duties caused by a relapse from bipolar disorder, leading to the postponement of the appeal court date. Previously, the Singaporean President, Halimah Yacob, had declined Nagaenthran's clemency request, asserting that he was receiving a fair trial. The new court date for Nagaenthran's appeal is now on 24th January 2022.

Nagaenthran's appeal will be heard by a panel of five judges, including Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon and Judges of Appeal Andrew Phang, Judith Prakash, Belinda Ang, and Senior Judge Chao Hick Tin. His lawyer, M Ravi, has been replaced by Violet Netto. As the court date approaches, international figures like Stephen Fry are urging Singapore to grant clemency to Nagaenthran, who faces a final appeal and potential death sentence.

Nagaenthran's final appeal was heard by the panel of judges on 1 March 2022, following a granted adjournment on 24 January 2022. His lawyer, Violet Netto, presented arguments for Nagaenthran to undergo a psychiatric evaluation to determine his mental fitness for execution and attempted to submit reports from two foreign psychologists as evidence to strengthen his case.

In the final appeal hearing on 1st of March 2022, Nagaenthran's lawyer, Violet Netto, presented evidence in the form of reports from two foreign psychologists to support his case and requested a psychiatric evaluation to determine his mental fitness for execution. However, the judges rejected the evidence due to it being submitted last-minute, viewing it as an abuse of the court process. The Deputy Public Prosecutor, Wong Woon Kwong, criticized Netto for attempting to suppress the prison's independent medical records and described the appeal as a cynical attempt to manipulate the legal process.

After the March 1st hearing, Nagaenthran remained in Changi Prison as advocacy groups campaigned for clemency during the verdict delay. However, four weeks later, the Court of Appeal, comprised of five judges, rejected the appeal and denounced both Netto and M. Ravi for misusing the legal process.

Following the March 1st hearing, Nagaenthran remained in Changi Prison while advocacy groups campaigned for clemency during the verdict delay. However, four weeks later, the Court of Appeal, consisting of five judges, dismissed the appeal, criticizing Netto and Ravi for misusing the legal process. As the verdict was announced, Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon highlighted that the appeal was based on inadmissible evidence and Ravi's unsupported assumption that Nagaenthran had a mental age below 18. The court acknowledged Nagaenthran's borderline intellectual functioning but found no proof of a decline in his mental abilities during his 13-year imprisonment on death row.

After the March 1st hearing, Nagaenthran stayed in Changi Prison as advocacy groups sought clemency during the verdict delay. However, the Court of Appeal, comprised of five judges, later dismissed the appeal, criticizing the defense for misusing the legal process. The court found issue with the use of evidence from two foreign psychologists who did not personally assess Nagaenthran. Additionally, medical and psychiatric reports that could have provided insight into Nagaenthran's mental state were not admitted due to his legal team's objection based on medical confidentiality. The Chief Justice expressed concern that Nagaenthran attempted to withhold evidence regarding his medical condition after bringing it up as part of his defense.

Following the March 1st hearing, Nagaenthran remained in Changi Prison as advocacy groups advocated for clemency during the verdict delay. However, the Court of Appeal, consisting of five judges, later dismissed the appeal, criticizing the defense for misusing the legal process. The court took issue with the defense's use of evidence from two foreign psychologists who did not personally assess Nagaenthran and the rejection of medical and psychiatric reports due to the defense's objection based on medical confidentiality. The Chief Justice, Menon, inferred that Nagaenthran attempted to withhold evidence regarding his medical condition and accused his legal team of mounting a baseless challenge against the death penalty, describing it as an attempt to escape execution.

After the March 1st hearing, Nagaenthran stayed in Changi Prison as advocacy groups campaigned for clemency during the verdict postponement. Nevertheless, the Court of Appeal, comprising five judges, later rejected the appeal, criticizing the defense for misusing the legal process. The court found fault with the defense's use of evidence from two foreign psychologists who did not directly examine Nagaenthran and their rejection of medical and psychiatric reports due to the defense's objection based on medical confidentiality. Chief Justice Menon concluded that Nagaenthran tried to conceal evidence about his medical condition and accused his legal team of mounting a baseless challenge against the death penalty, labeling it an attempt to evade execution.

In the appeal verdict, Menon also reiterated that it is inappropriate to engage in or encourage last-minute attempts to reopen any concluded appeals without a valid basis. He emphasized that as long as the capital punishment was imposed legally in the specified circumstances, it is unacceptable for a defense counsel to persistently launch hopeless appeals that tarnish the reputation of the justice system. The court judged that the proceedings were a flagrant and inexcusable abuse of the court's processes, conducted with the apparent objective of unjustifiably delaying the execution of the sentence imposed on Nagaenthran.

After the Court of Appeal, consisting of five judges, dismissed Nagaenthran's final appeal for clemency, they criticized his defense team for misusing the legal process. The court found issues with the defense's reliance on evidence from foreign psychologists and their rejection of medical reports due to confidentiality concerns. Nagaenthran's family was understandably devastated and shocked by the dismissal. Despite this setback, various civil groups continued to advocate for Nagaenthran's sentence to be commuted and for Singapore to show him mercy. The court viewed the defense's actions as an abuse of the legal process, intended to unjustifiably delay the execution of Nagaenthran's sentence.

Maya Foa, Reprieve's director, and Lawyers for Liberty (LFL) appealed to Singapore's President Halimah Yacob for clemency on behalf of Nagaenthran, emphasizing global calls for mercy and alleging that Singapore's actions violate international law and disregard the prohibition on executing intellectually disabled individuals. Nagaenthran's family and other civil groups are still advocating for his sentence to be commuted.

Maya Foa, Reprieve's director, and Lawyers for Liberty, in association with M Ravi, urged the Malaysian government to take Nagaenthran's case to the International Court of Justice. Nagaenthran's mother, Panchalai Supermaniam, initiated a legal challenge against Singapore's Chief Justice, Sundaresh Menon, on April 25, 2022, with support from relatives, activists, and friends. She accused Menon of previously serving as the attorney general who prosecuted Nagaenthran, resulting in his conviction. The lawsuit asserts that this action "clearly" infringed upon her son's right to a fair trial.

In the legal challenge, Panchalai, Nagaenthran's mother, proceeded without legal representation, as no lawyers in Singapore agreed to represent her due to potential court repercussions, which might include substantial fines and penalties for unsubstantiated applications.

Nagaenthran's mother, Panchalai, had to represent herself in the legal challenge due to the reluctance of lawyers in Singapore to participate, fearing potential repercussions. However, the Court of Appeal, composed of judges Belinda Ang, Andrew Phang, and Judith Prakash, dismissed her lawsuit the day before Nagaenthran's execution, deeming it meritless.

The Court of Appeal, including Judge Phang, decided that Panchalai's legal challenge was unfounded and had been filed to unnecessarily prolong the legal process. They pointed out that Nagaenthran had not raised this issue in his previous appeal, suggesting it was a deliberate attempt to challenge the finality of the court's decision. Judge Phang emphasized that there is a point when the court's decision must be accepted as the last word.

The Court of Appeal, including Judge Phang, concluded that the legal action by Panchalai, Nagaenthran's mother, was a baseless attempt to extend the legal process and undermine the finality of the court's decision. This was highlighted by Nagaenthran not raising the issue in his previous appeal. Nagaenthran, accepting the court's verdict, made a request to spend time with his family and hold their hands before his execution. The judges granted him two hours together with his family in the Supreme Court building, permitting a final, heartfelt farewell.

Nagaenthran bid farewell to his family at the Supreme Court before being taken to Changi Prison for his execution. After 13 years of imprisonment for drug trafficking, Nagaenthran was executed at Changi Prison on April 27, 2022.

Nagaenthran was the second individual executed in Singapore after a two-year moratorium on death row prisoners due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the first being Abdul Kahar Othman. He was the fifth Malaysian drug trafficker put to death in Singapore since 2016. Upon his execution, Nagaenthran's family, including his 22-year-old brother Navinkumar, planned to collect his body and transport it to their hometown in Ipoh for funeral preparations.

Nagaenthran's sister, Sharmila, expressed the family's sadness and disappointment about his execution, despite accepting his fate. The funeral was set for April 29, 2022, two days after his execution.

Nagaenthran's sister, Sharmila, shared plans for her brother's burial in a Hindu cemetery in Buntong, Ipoh, following the funeral in Singapore. She specified that around 200 family members and friends attended the funeral, but politely declined the presence of politicians, who she believed were seeking publicity rather than providing support during Nagaenthran's time on death row. Erwin van der Borght, Director of Amnesty International, described Nagaenthran's execution as a "disgraceful act" that was "ruthlessly carried out" by the Singaporean government, despite global protests. Julian McMahon, a human rights lawyer, criticized the use of the death penalty in general, following Nagaenthran's execution, a practice he had previously opposed during the cases of Andrew Chan, Myuran Sukumaran, and Van Tuong Nguyen.

Erwin van der Borght and Julian McMahon strongly criticize the use of the death penalty, with McMahon arguing that it doesn't prevent drug trafficking and is disturbingly applied to what he considers "non-serious" crimes. McMahon also points out that those punished are typically small-time offenders rather than the masterminds behind the operations. Similarly, Morry Bailes expresses disapproval of Singapore and Japan's use of capital punishment, referencing Nagaenthran's execution and Japan's execution of three murderers the previous year.

Bailes challenges the assertion that the death penalty acts as a deterrent, highlighting that many countries' experiences contradict this claim. He argues that executing a low-level offender like Nagaenthran does not serve justice, as the mastermind behind the crime remains unpunished. Furthermore, Bailes emphasizes the irreversibility of capital punishment, pointing out the possibility of errors in the judicial process involving witnesses, juries, and courts.

The execution of Nagaenthran and Abdul Kahar Othman by Singapore drew criticism from activists and the United Nations, who are against the death penalty. Following the execution of Nagaenthran, the Attorney-General's Chambers released a statement rejecting the allegations and unfounded rumors about supposed bias from Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon in Nagaenthran's case, emphasizing that these rumors were false and inappropriate.

The Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) stated that the lawsuit against Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon is the seventh legal action (excluding appeals) taken for Nagaenthran's case. They view this lawsuit as an abuse of the court's procedures and an unwarranted attempt to postpone the enforcement of Nagaenthran's lawful sentence.

In the context of the lawsuit against Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon regarding Nagaenthran's case, the Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) highlighted that they had previously informed Nagaenthran's legal counsel about Menon's appointment as Attorney General while Nagaenthran was being prosecuted. Despite this knowledge, Nagaenthran, following his lawyer's advice, did not raise any objections to Menon presiding over the case.

The AGC argues that Nagaenthran's mother was not deliberately withheld from information about Menon's appointment as Attorney General, as she filed the lawsuit with the help of friends and activists, and the legal documents contained signatures and email addresses that did not belong to her. Thus, they claim there was no valid basis for her to raise objections in the lawsuit.

The AGC contended that Nagaenthran's mother lacked grounds to challenge Menon's appointment as Attorney General, as she didn't personally file the lawsuit and the legal documents contained unrelated signatures and email addresses. The AGC considers these allegations to be contempt of court and is prepared to take necessary action to safeguard the justice system. Following Nagaenthran's execution on April 28, 2022, the AGC and Central Narcotics Bureau released statements defending Singapore's choice to carry out the death penalty despite international criticism.

The AGC and CNB released statements following Nagaenthran's execution, asserting that he received a fair trial and had exhausted all legal appeals over a decade. The CNB emphasized that Nagaenthran's criminal actions were deliberate and calculated, with judges concurring that he understood his actions at the time. They also addressed misinformation regarding Nagaenthran's mental state. The AGC is prepared to protect the justice system against contempt.

After Nagaenthran's execution, both the AGC and CNB released statements claiming that he had a fair trial and had exhausted all legal options over a decade. The CNB specifically addressed misinformation about Nagaenthran's mental state, clarifying that he was not intellectually disabled at the time of his offense. This was supported by his attempts to avoid authorities and his provision of multiple inconsistent explanations for his actions. The CNB stressed that Nagaenthran's criminal behavior was intentional and calculated, with judges concurring that he was aware of his actions. The AGC is ready to defend the justice system from contempt.

Following Nagaenthran's execution, the AGC and CNB released statements asserting that he received a fair trial and had no remaining legal options. The CNB refuted claims about Nagaenthran's mental state, stating that his actions were intentional and calculated. The government, supported by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan, maintained that Nagaenthran underwent complete legal proceedings before his execution, as they responded to Malaysian officials' letter requesting a case review.

After Nagaenthran's execution, Malaysia's Foreign Minister, Saifuddin Abdullah, acknowledged the event and assured Singapore of undisturbed diplomatic relations, recognizing Singapore's sovereignty over its judicial system. Simultaneously, Singapore's Ambassador, Umej Bhatia, defended the government's execution of Nagaenthran and Abdul Kahar Othman, as well as the use of the death penalty for drug-related offenses, in response to the UN's criticism.

In response to the UN's criticism of the executions, Singapore's Ambassador, Umej Bhatia, defended the use of the death penalty for drug-related offenses, stating that all criminal proceedings in Singapore follow due process in an impartial and independent judiciary. He emphasized Singapore's longstanding reputation for a fair and impartial justice system and an independent and effective judiciary, where the death penalty is imposed only if a suspect's guilt is proven according to the law.

Bhatia disputed claims of racial bias in Singapore's use of the death penalty for drug-related offenses, asserting equal and fair treatment for all individuals under the law, regardless of race or nationality. He also argued against the need for a moratorium, stating that there is no international agreement against the death penalty when it is imposed according to due process, and there is no clear definition of "most serious crimes" under international law.

Bhatia maintains that Singapore's use of the death penalty for drug offenses is free from racial bias, emphasizing equal treatment under the law and questioning the definition of "most serious crimes" in international law. He asserts Singapore's sovereign right to shape its criminal justice system according to its needs and international obligations. Minister Faishal Ibrahim shares this view, acknowledging differing opinions on capital punishment but insisting on respect for the law, particularly in regards to Nagaenthran's case, where frivolous appeals without substantial evidence are not acceptable.

Bhatia and Minister Faishal Ibrahim argue that Singapore's application of the death penalty for drug offenses is impartial and in line with national and international laws. They support adjustments to legislation to prevent misuse of court processes and emphasize the harmful consequences of drug abuse. Faishal points to recent violent incidents as evidence of the destructive impact of drug abuse on individuals and society.

In a 2022 BBC HARDtalk interview, Shanmugam defended Singapore's use of the death penalty for drug offenses, emphasizing it as a necessary measure to safeguard citizens and prevent drug-related fatalities, which the WHO's 2021 report indicated reached 500,000 in a single year. Despite growing liberal attitudes among young people, he maintained that the nation's war on drugs would persist. In the 2022 BBC HARDtalk interview, Shanmugam highlighted that the number of drug-related arrests in Singapore has decreased from 6,000 annually in the 1990s to approximately 3,000 per year currently. This decline, according to Shanmugam, demonstrates the effectiveness of Singapore's drug trafficking laws in protecting citizens and preserving a safe society by reducing drug-related incidents.

In the 2022 BBC HARDtalk interview, when questioned about the execution of Nagaenthran, Shanmugam defended the decision by stating that the courts determined Nagaenthran was not intellectually disabled, and he knowingly and intentionally smuggled drugs into Singapore, demonstrating that the country's strict drug trafficking laws are applied fairly and without regard for disability status.

In the 2022 BBC HARDtalk interview, Shanmugam argued that Nagaenthran's execution was fair because he was found not intellectually disabled and knowingly trafficked drugs, upholding Singapore's strict drug laws regardless of disability. To emphasize the broader issue, Shanmugam referred to the execution of two American drug traffickers with comparable IQs and quoted "a single hanging of a drug trafficker is a tragedy; a million deaths from drug abuse is a statistic," highlighting the severe drug situation in Southeast Asia causing numerous fatalities among drug abusers.

After the BBC interview, Shanmugam's stance on Nagaenthran's execution was met with public approval on social media, as they agreed with Singapore's strict drug laws and the fairness of the punishment, considering the severity of the drug issue in Southeast Asia.

Opposition parties in Singapore, including Reform Party, People's Power Party, and Red Dot United, expressed their concerns to Law Minister K Shanmugam about the alleged climate of fear among lawyers, who may be hesitant to represent drug traffickers on death row due to potential government backlash. This worry arises from the recent cases of Nagaenthran and Datchinamurthy, who had to appear in court without legal representation.

The opposition parties, including Reform Party, People's Power Party, and Red Dot United, have raised concerns to Law Minister K Shanmugam about the perceived reluctance of lawyers to represent death row drug traffickers due to potential backlash, which may tarnish Singapore's reputation. At a litigation conference in May 2022, Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon acknowledged an increasing trend of unfounded legal challenges against the death penalty, particularly in Nagaenthran's case, which he viewed as a misuse of the court process.

The Chief Justice, Sundaresh Menon, has urged lawyers in Singapore to refrain from making baseless challenges to the death penalty, as seen in Nagaenthran's case. He considers this kind of behavior an abuse of the court process, which undermines legal officers' responsibility to the court. Menon's remarks follow concerns raised by opposition parties about the lack of legal representation for death row drug traffickers due to potential backlash. Following the Chief Justice's call to avoid abusing the court process, it was revealed that Nagaenthran's former lawyer, Violet Netto, faced legal proceedings for practicing without a valid certificate. This reportedly occurred in Nagaenthran's case and in the final appeals of two other death row inmates, Pausi Jefridin and Roslan Bakar. This development underscores the importance of upholding professional standards and maintaining the integrity of the legal system.

The text indicates that, according to the law, lawyers like Violet Netto are required to obtain a practicing certificate for each year they work as an advocate and solicitor. It is mentioned that Netto's certificate had expired when she represented Nagaenthran, which highlights the significance of adhering to professional standards to preserve the legitimacy of the legal system.

The text suggests that if lawyers like Violet Netto practice without a valid annual certificate, they could be penalized with up to six months in jail, a fine of S$2,500, or both. In the case of Netto's client, Nagaenthran, both she and the human rights lawyer who previously represented him, M Ravi, faced professional consequences due to lapsed certificates. Ravi also faced multiple disciplinary inquiries, contempt proceedings, and police investigations for allegedly misusing court processes in Nagaenthran's case. These consequences emphasize the importance of upholding professional standards to maintain the integrity of the legal system.

The text mentions that Ravi, another lawyer involved in Nagaenthran's case, faced additional consequences such as a travel ban, preventing him from going to Malaysia. This, along with the professional repercussions for both Netto and Ravi, prompted criticism from human rights groups and Malaysian lawyers. They accused Singapore of harassing lawyers and insisted that it respect the right to legal representation for criminals, as Nagaenthran's mother and another prisoner, Datchinamurthy Kataiah, were left without legal counsel. The Court of Appeal issued a court order on May 25, 2022, in this context.

In summary, the text discusses the professional consequences faced by lawyers Netto and Ravi, which led to criticism from rights groups and Malaysian lawyers, who emphasized the importance of legal representation and raised concerns about harassment. The Court of Appeal's order is also mentioned.

The Court of Appeal ordered lawyers Netto and Ravi to reimburse more than S$20,000 in costs to the Attorney-General's Chambers due to their unsubstantiated lawsuits in Nagaenthran's case, with Ravi responsible for 75% and Netto for 25%. This development emerged in the context of professional consequences for the lawyers, which sparked criticism from human rights groups and Malaysian lawyers emphasizing the right to legal representation and expressing concerns about harassment.

A fundraising event was organized to assist Netto and Ravi in paying their fines, with critics arguing that they are being penalized for performing their professional duties. Ravi, who also has to pay for two additional lawsuits, remains defiant and unrepentant, maintaining that his efforts to save lives from capital punishment, despite government criticism, come with a high cost. Additionally, there is an ongoing police investigation of the activists involved.

The police are investigating activists, including Kirsten Han and Rocky Howe, who allegedly held unauthorized protests outside Changi Prison against the death penalty and in support of two condemned drug traffickers. The activists were asked to surrender their anti-death penalty shirts, handphones, and other items as evidence for the ongoing investigation. This investigation is part of the larger context of the fundraising event for Netto and Ravi, who were fined for performing their professional duties and are facing criticism and legal penalties.

The authorities have recently enacted the Post-Appeal Applications in Capital Cases Bill, which tightens the regulations surrounding capital punishment appeals. This development is happening in conjunction with the investigation of activists like Kirsten Han and Rocky Howe, who have been protesting against the death penalty and advocating for two prisoners on death row. This new bill aims to strengthen the legal framework around capital punishment, which is a significant issue in the current context of the ongoing investigation and the legal penalties faced by Netto and Ravi.

The Post-Appeal Applications in Capital Cases Bill was enacted after Nagaenthran's execution, in response to the rising number of court process abuses in capital drug cases that had already gone through appeals and clemency. This new law empowers the Court of Appeal, Singapore's highest court, to be the only body that can postpone an execution and consider post-appeal applications for prisoners facing capital punishment. This development is relevant in the ongoing investigation of activists like Kirsten Han and Rocky Howe, and the legal penalties faced by Netto and Ravi, as it further strengthens the legal framework around capital punishment.

The Post-Appeal Applications in Capital Cases Bill, enacted after Nagaenthran's execution, aims to address court process abuses in capital drug cases that have already gone through appeals and clemency. Under this law, if a prisoner is found to have misused court processes, they can't make a post-appeal application unless new evidence emerges. A single judge will initially review the case and decide whether to delay the execution and approve the post-appeal application, followed by a panel of three or five judges in the Court of Appeal. The bill was drafted and passed on 29th November 2022, further solidifying the legal structure around capital punishment. This development is significant in the ongoing investigation of activists like Kirsten Han and Rocky Howe and the legal consequences faced by Netto and Ravi.

The Post-Appeal Applications in Capital Cases Bill was introduced and passed on 29th November 2022, to prevent abuse of court processes in capital drug cases that have exhausted appeals and clemency. The law allows a single judge to initially review the case before it goes to a panel of three or five judges in the Court of Appeal, but Human Rights Watch criticized it as a move to limit inmates' opportunities to contest their executions and access to final justice. Most politicians, including the Leader of Opposition Pritam Singh, supported the bill. This development is relevant to the ongoing investigation of activists like Kirsten Han and Rocky Howe and the legal consequences faced by Netto and Ravi.
